Fields.DialogueText: We're under attack! Quickly, we need to retreat!
Unfortunately, Captain, I could never do something so cowardly. Leave this to me.
Cossack, we're outnumbered! You can't possibly--
*Peck*
Cossack...
Thank you for worrying about me. I'll be going now.
What am I supposed to do if you go so far...
@BATTLE
Enemies have been eliminated, Captain.

Fields.MenuText: Are you injured at all?

Fields.DialogueText: Barely a scratch.

Fields.MenuText: Must you always be so reckless?

Fields.DialogueText: I'd hate to say you knew what you were signing up for, Captain, but...

Fields.MenuText: My orders appear to have fallen on deaf ears.

Fields.DialogueText: Your orders are absolute, Captain. Just, some are more absolute than others and this was a particularly lax command.
I'm surprised you let me go so easily.
That's because you...
Ah, I see. We haven't really spoken much since that day, have we?
Everything's just kind of been left up in the air.
Although I don't dislike this approach. Let's take things slowly.
Agreed.
*MEOW*
GAH! We agreed to take things slowly, but we have already produced a healthy litter!
I'm starting to agree that we may need to re-house at least some of them...
Starting with the mangy black one!
At our next pit stop, let's see if we can find some homes for these guys.
With pleasure!
We managed to find homes for our guests fairly easily.
I'm not too surprised. Normal people, when faced with an adorable kitten, choose to pet it instead of viciously berate it.
Hmph! Let's just hurry this up. We have one fleabag left.

Fields.MenuText: Just because this cat happens to be black doesn't mean you have to hate him so vehemently.

Fields.DialogueText: You show me a a cute harbinger of evil, Captain, and I'll show you a harbinger of evil.

Fields.MenuText: I thought you were warming to him. He is wearing a collar of your favorite color, after all.

Fields.DialogueText: I told you before, Captain, that must have been a prank by the other crew members!

Fields.MenuText: Maybe we could get a goldfish next time...

Fields.DialogueText: It isn't cats that I hate per se. It's the omen black cats imply.
Hold up, Cossack. Approaching the port... Can you see that?
Morganas! They must be trying to pillage the town!
*MEOW*
Wait, Cat! No matter how ominous you may be, I can't let you fall into even more tainted hands!
@BATTLE
What a display, Cossack. You practically parted the sea to try and rescue the cat when taking down those Morganas.
It couldn't be helped. I wouldn't wish death on anyone, friend or foe alike. Aside from the Morganas, obviously.
You and Moses make a great team!
Moses?
I thought maybe, if we gave him a name, it would help you warm to him. After that display, Moses seemed like an obvious fit!
Captain, I've been advocating that we get rid of these cats from the moment they hopped on board!

Fields.MenuText: We have to leave soon and I can't see any takers.

Fields.DialogueText: Feel free to go on ahead. After I find a suitable owner, I'll swim the distance to find you again!

Fields.MenuText: Perhaps I've come around to him.

Fields.DialogueText: The path we walk is perilous, Captain. I find it difficult to protect YOU at times and now I'm expected to risk my life for a pet?!

Fields.MenuText: I think keeping him on board will be good for you. Maybe you can finally kick that fear of bad omens once and for all.

Fields.DialogueText: Captain, you make your life on the sea! How can you possibly look the other way when a literal "black spot" is placed on your doorstep?!
*ALARM*
I can hear that from here! That's our cue to leave, Cossack! Quickly, bring Moses!
Ugh! … Don't get in my way…
*MEOW*
@BATTLE
New orders, Cossack. We're to take our talents to Jøssingfjord, Norway. Several men have been taken captive by the Morganas and we're to free them.
I've been itching to get back to business.
That's not all. After completing said mission, we'll be making our way to Narvik. Several Morganas have been sighted in the area and an attack seems imminent.
I understand.

Fields.MenuText: What do you know about Norway?

Fields.DialogueText: Aside from the names of several locations, very little. However, I'm confident in my ability to adapt to any surroundings.

Fields.MenuText: The first half of this mission will be strictly covert. Can you handle that?

Fields.DialogueText: As long as I'm given the freedom to let loose in Narvik, I foresee no problems.

Fields.MenuText: I need you to understand that if even one prisoner dies, this mission will be counted as a failure.

Fields.DialogueText: I would never wish death on anyone, Captain. However, when it comes to the greater good, sometimes I struggle to comprehend your reasoning.
First thing's first. We'll restock for the long road ahead. We'll likely be unable to rest for a while.
Aye-aye, Captain!
*ALARM*
Excellent timing! We can get some practice in for the battles ahead. Cossack, with me!
Da!
@BATTLE
We're fully stocked on essentials, Captain.
Good to hear.
All that's left are potential upgrades to our firepower. There are several weapon vendors nearby. Would you like to check them out?

Fields.MenuText: As soon as we're finished loading the cargo, we can make our way over.

Fields.DialogueText: I can't wait!

Fields.MenuText: I think you're strong enough to take down an entire fleet as is.

Fields.DialogueText: Flattery will get you everywhere, Captain.
*ALARM*
The first of many, it seems...
Don't worry, Captain. I'll protect you no matter what.
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: Already got a line on some guns. The fleet could use an upgrade.

Fields.DialogueText: I suppose I can't have all the Morganas to myself.
Look sharp, Cossack. We're in enemy waters...
Captain, over there. It looks to be a scouting Morgana vessel.
Can you take it out discreetly? The mother ship must be nearby.
I'll do my best, but no promises!
@BATTLE
I'm impressed, Cossack. I didn't know you had it in you.
To be perfectly honest, neither did I.

Fields.MenuText: Where's this change of heart come from?

Fields.DialogueText: I've always been focused on the mission in front of me. Willing to sacrifice anything to achieve victory. However, recently, I've discovered several things I'd prefer not to part with if possible.

Fields.MenuText: Can I expect this kind of compliance from now on?

Fields.DialogueText: Don't push it, Captain.

Fields.MenuText: I'm glad you've decided to take better care of yourself.

Fields.DialogueText: *Ahem* Thank you for the kind words, Captain. They are entirely unnecessary but they are appreciated...
On the horizon. That looks to be our target. Remember, Cossack, nobody dies.
Da, Captain.
How do you think I feel? The interior of this prisoner transport's engine room... it is similar in design to our own, isn't it?
Likely a way for the Morganas to memorize the layouts of our ships. Don't be fooled. We're aboard a Morgana vessel and we mustn't forget it.
Over--! Over there... The prisoners...
Everyone but the captain has passed out. He must have stayed awake to ensure no further harm came to his crew. Can you stand?
I can barely keep my eyes open.
We'll have to carry them out.
Please, take the crew first. Their lives are more important than anything. I don't expect a destroyer to understand, but--
I'll do my best to extricate your crew without harm. Please trust in my ability.
Oh... Thank you very much, ma'am.

Fields.MenuText: I always knew you were a giant softie.

Fields.DialogueText: Shh! Now's not the time, Captain!

Fields.MenuText: I'm proud of you, Cossack.

Fields.DialogueText: There's still so much for us to learn about ourselves in this life. I'm looking forward to doing so together with you, Captain.

Fields.MenuText: Could I expect such kind words were I to be captured?

Fields.DialogueText: If you fell prey to a Morgana attack, I'd have to rethink my loyalty. I couldn't possibly work under someone so easily abducted.
*ALARM*
They're on to us. Cossack, it's time to escape. Once the crew are safe aboard our ship, you're free to run rampant!
Don't regret those words, Captain!
@BATTLE
Let's make this quick. I don't like towing this thing.
Safe and sound. Now, as per our agreement?
I'll take care of the crew. I'm counting on you out there.
@BATTLE
Captain, I've returned. Where are the prisoners?
They're resting up in the sick bay. The captain wanted to express his gratitude to you once again, but fell unconscious midway through.
That's sweet, albeit a little concerning.

Fields.MenuText: You made it out of that alive without much issue.

Fields.DialogueText: I know what you're implying, Captain. Maybe I was too harsh on Moses. For the physical incarnation of doom and despair, he is kind of cute...

Fields.MenuText: Be sure to reply to him once he wakes up.

Fields.DialogueText: Of course, Captain. I always pay my utmost respect to any and all authority figures. You know that, right?

Fields.MenuText: He's in our hands and not the Morganas'. That's all that matters.

Fields.DialogueText: Da, Kapitan, almost all.
Well, then. Onward to Narvik.
What about--?
We'll drop them off somewhere along the way. They can rest up while we continue the mission. After they're healed, we can take them back to their respective ships.
Captain, your forward thinking would make you a dangerous enemy. I'm glad we're on the same team.
As am I, Cossack. As am I.
*DROP*
Captain, are you busy?
Always, but I can spare a second or two.
It seems some of the crew weren't as injured as we thought.
Is that so?
Apparently, the captain took the brunt of the attacks as tribute for his crew.
How noble.
In any case, now that most of them have woken up, they've informed me that they'd like to continue their journey under your command.
Oho? Interesting.
In an effort to be more respectful, I thought I would check with you before signing off on the idea.

Fields.MenuText: We can always use a few extra deckhands!

Fields.DialogueText: I thought as much. I'll let them know the good news!

Fields.MenuText: Those men may be more injured than they're letting on. I won't take any potential risks aboard this ship.

Fields.DialogueText: Of course, Captain. I'll inform the crew that, after they've rested for some time, we will reconsider their application.
*ALARM*
We must be getting closer to Narvik.
Leave it to me, Captain!
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: I'll find a place for them, even if it's not aboard you.

Fields.DialogueText: Wherever they can be useful, Captain.
What beautiful scenery Narvik has. The flowers are breathtaking.

Fields.MenuText: I'll have to get you another bouqet sometime.

Fields.DialogueText: Captain, please... Not while we're on duty. Although, I won't reject such a considerate offer...

Fields.MenuText: Sunflowers are your favorite, right?

Fields.DialogueText: You remembered! That means more to me than you might think, thank you.

Fields.MenuText: Now you see why we must rid such a place of its Morgana infestation.

Fields.DialogueText: Seconded!
Don't gaze at them for too long. We have company.
*ALARM*
There's so many...
More than you can handle?
Ha! Who are you talking to?! Depending on your sensitivity to violence, Captain, you may want to look away from what's about to happen.
Ha! Who are YOU talking to?!
I hope watching such a display doesn't...
Doesn't...?
Doesn't make you think of me any differently...
I knew what I was signing up for when I partnered with you. I'm in love with YOU, Cossack. From your love of sunflowers to your love of destructive warfare.
That's the first time you've said that since that day.
But I've never stopped feeling such a way all this time.
*Peck*
What was that for?
I love you too, Captain. Please make sure Moses is deep inside the ship. I'll be back momentarily.
@BATTLE
I know I requested we take things slow, but...
Slower than you during a Morgana battle, but faster than a glacier. I think I've got it.
Incredible... Watching her dance across the deck like this... I'm falling in love all over again.
*Thud*
Captain! Is everything all right? I thought I could see your lips moving but I couldn't hear your orders. What did you say?
N-nothing, Cossack. You've nearly dispatched the entire fleet. Are you okay to keep going?
Don't wait up, Captain!
@BATTLE
That looks like the last of them.
Captain… Are you injured… at…
*Thud*
Cossack!
Apologies, Captain. I may have given things a little extra gusto after reading your lips from the battlefield…

Fields.MenuText: I should have kept my mouth shut and you'd have been fine.

Fields.DialogueText: No, your words touched me and I'm glad I could hear-- read them…

Fields.MenuText: Are you hurt?

Fields.DialogueText: Just fatigued. I should be fine in a few hours…

Fields.MenuText: Thanks to you, Narvik is saved.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm relieved. We'll have to come back here someday for a stroll…
Let me help you.
W-w-w-what are you doing, Captain?!
You can't move, right? I'll carry you to your quarters.
How undignified…
Stop resisting and save your strength. That battle must have taken a heavy toll on you.
Did you just call me heavy?!
Quickly, now! To the ship's interior!
Captain, sorry to bother you...
Don't be absurd, Cossack.
Now that things have quieted down, I've realised my necklace has gone missing.

Fields.MenuText: When did you last have it?
Do you have any idea where it could be?

Fields.DialogueText: I fear it may be lost at the bottom of the ocean somewhere.
I think I remember it falling off during our tussle in Narvik.

Fields.MenuText: Would you like me to help you look?

Fields.DialogueText: Thank you, Captain, but I wouldn't waste your strength.
*ALARM*
Don't give up hope, Cossack. We'll find it, I promise.
You shouldn't make promises you can't keep, Captain...
@BATTLE
Any luck with the net, Cossack?
This is hopeless, Captain. Even if it did fall into the sea, something of which I am not 100% certain, it has likely been gobbled up by a hungry fish by now.

Fields.MenuText: Don't lose hope, Cossack. It doesn't suit you.

Fields.DialogueText: That's true enough at least...

Fields.MenuText: Perhaps I should go for a little swim.

Fields.DialogueText: No, Captain! I would never ask you to go so far...

Fields.MenuText: Could I just buy you a replacement?

Fields.DialogueText: As much as I would love a gift from you, that necklace was rather special to me.
What was inside the pendant?
Cossack?
Sorry, Captain. I've never told anyone what was inside that pendant. Not even my closest friends. I don't think I could muster the strength to reveal it.
Am I a close friend?
No. That's what I've come to realise. I think, in our current relationship, I'd be happy to tell you.
*ALARM*
We may have to hold fire for a little while, Cossack!
I'm ready whenever you are, Captain!
@BATTLE
Inside that pendant was a short prayer.
A prayer?
You're more than aware of my religious beliefs by now, I assume.
Of course.
I will proudly proclaim my beliefs from the rooftops, but this particular prayer doesn't inspire the kind of ruthless battle strategy that I'm known for.
What did it say?
It was about love.

Fields.MenuText: Love?
Is that so embarrassing?

Fields.DialogueText: For a destroyer renowned for her 100% mission completion rate, I worry if people knew that I was reliant on a prayer about love to keep myself motivated, they would lose faith.
Silly, right?

Fields.MenuText: That's why you could only tell me now?

Fields.DialogueText: Now we've professed our love for one another, I hoped you could understand.
What was the quote?
*ALARM*
I struggle to remember it word for word. I'll adjourn to my room and fetch my bible after dealing with these Morganas.
@BATTLE
Corinthians 13:13: "And now these three remain: faith, hope and love. But the greatest of these is love."
That's beautiful.
I never thought I would be able to experience such emotions as a destroyer. My mission is my livelihood. I have no time to waste on emotions like love.
Cossack...
Still, I hoped that, one day, I would be able to find that what I was looking for. Now I can say for certainty that "I have found the one whom my soul loves." - Song of Solomon 3:4.

Fields.MenuText: I can say the same.

Fields.DialogueText: Embarrassing...

Fields.MenuText: Your knowledge of scripture is incredible.

Fields.DialogueText: It's very important to me. I'm sure you could recite the last forty years of naval history without batting an eye.

Fields.MenuText: Everyone is deserving of love.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm starting to see that. Except for those Morganas, of course.
*ALARM*
It may not be able to replace what you've lost, Cossack, but I'd like to buy you a gift. Let's replace your necklace and inspire you with something new.
I'd like that very much.
@BATTLE
How about this, Cossack?
What is...?
It's a dandelion pendant. I thought it could replace your lost treasure. We can place the same quote inside.
It's beautiful, Captain. Are you sure?
With this, I can buy you some flowers and a necklace all at once! Of course. It's a little pricey, but you can't put a price on lo--
Thank you for breaking off, Captain. You saved us both a round of embarrassment...
Is there anything else we need while we're here?
We've expended a lot of artillery recently. Would you like to restock our ammunition?

Fields.MenuText: While we're here we may as well.
I think we'll be fine.

Fields.DialogueText: Understood.
I'll make a list of what we need.
Morganas seem to have tailed us to this port. We should deal with them now to ensure a smooth exit.
Aye-aye, Captain!
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: Always. I appreciate you being on top of it.

Fields.DialogueText: You'll never know what it's like to be out of ammunition, Captain... but it's worse than hunger.
Moses seems very content with life aboard ship, doesn't he, Captain?
Perhaps the little fellow has a taste for Morgana blood.
I wouldn't have phrased it quite so morbidly but, whatever the case, I am glad he is well-settled.

Fields.MenuText: Do you think it's because he has two loving parents?

Fields.DialogueText: Parents? All things considered, a cat is probably the furthest I'd like to dive into THAT adventure at present.

Fields.MenuText: Have you concluded that he is not so unlucky?

Fields.DialogueText: Perhaps, Moses is the exception that proves the rule. I will not throw my beliefs into the garbage so easily.

Fields.MenuText: Maybe we could bring him with us into the field?

Fields.DialogueText: I know you're joking, Captain, but the notion still fills me with a great deal of worry.
I think it's time we test whether Moses will be a burden to us from now on.
How do you propose we do that?
*ALARM*
By seeing just how many terribly volatile situations we can place ourselves in and whether, with Moses in our company, we can make it through to the other side!
@BATTLE
Captain. A report has come in. We're to extricate some allies from Morgana waters up ahead.
Perfect! Let's see if Moses brings us luck in the battles ahead.
I still don't quite understand what you plan to do. Do you intend to have Moses watch our six while taking out the Morganas?
I am not fond of animal cruelty despite what you may think. I think leaving Moses in the bridge as a beacon watching over us will do fine.
That's a relief.
*ALARM*
Okay, Moses. It's your time to shine. Bring us luck in the battles ahead.
*MEW*
@BATTLE
That went off without a hitch!
It was only a scouting party, Captain. I'm sure you can't give Moses all the credit for dispatching so few enemies.

Fields.MenuText: If you believe so wholeheartedly in bad luck, do you also feel the same about good luck?

Fields.DialogueText: I certainly do. Good fortune is what brought me to you in the first place. Of course, luck is no substitute for hard work and dedication.

Fields.MenuText: Which omen are you most wary of?

Fields.DialogueText: There are countless bad luck omens in Britain. Breaking a mirror, spilling salt, opening an umbrella inside... Magpies, however, I am the most wary of.
Magpies?
One for sorrow, two for joy, three for a girl, four for a boy, five for silver, six for gold, seven for a secret never to be told.
Interesting.
Isn't it?! You can also counteract the bad luck of a single magpie by saluting it and proclaiming "Good morning, Mr. Magpie!"
Let's press on. With Moses at our side, we can't possibly fail!

Fields.MenuText: Do you have any proof these bad omens are real?

Fields.DialogueText: Of course! I was once observing a single magpie; they are known to bring bad luck. I was so distracted that I nearly crashed into the harbor! What more proof do you need?!
Magpies mate for life, so seeing one on its own means it has lost its mate... or has yet to find one.
Our target is in the distance, Captain! Your orders?
With our good luck charm, how can we lose? Give them hell!
@BATTLE
You may be right about Moses, Captain. I've never felt so at ease when taking down Morganas.

Fields.MenuText: Do you normally feel anxious?

Fields.DialogueText: Less anxious and more focused. Regardless of the enemy in front of me, I will never underestimate anyone.

Fields.MenuText: You really enjoy your livelihood, huh, Cossack?

Fields.DialogueText: Can you blame me? Purging this world from those who seek to destroy it. What better feeling could there be?!

Fields.MenuText: Good luck charms date back since time began. There must be some truth to them, don't you think?

Fields.DialogueText: For such an idea to persist long into our time, I would have to agree with you, Captain.
That is why I am confident that, in years to come, future generations will not be able to remember the Morganas at all!
Maybe we could put Moses's ability to a little test outside of combat.
What did you have in mind?
What do you say to a friendly game of chess? If I win with Moses by my side, you must admit your worries of bad luck are unfounded.
Interesting. I may not change my beliefs, but even uttering such a phrase as a lie would be a terrible blow to my pride. What do I receive if I win?
What do you want?
Hmm. I'll let you know when it's time! To the mess hall!
This is getting pretty intense...

Fields.MenuText: Maybe I'll let you off easier if you admit defeat now.

Fields.DialogueText: Not a chance!

Fields.MenuText: Back against the wall; is the great Cossack planning on retreating?

Fields.DialogueText: You really don't know me at all, do you, Captain?

Fields.MenuText: I think you've been playing fairly well.

Fields.DialogueText: Chess sharpens the mind when it comes to real combat. I try to play with like-minded individuals whenever I get the chance.
*ALARM*
Check!
*MEOW*
Gah! I can't concentrate with that blaring siren distracting me. Pray we deal with these Morganas and then return to finish things off.
As you wish, but I have the next twenty to thirty moves already planned.
I would expect nothing less of the person I've chosen to follow. Let's see how well your tactical knowledge translates to real time action!
@BATTLE
Checkmate!
Ah! I didn't even see that! And with only a queen and a rook!
Ohohoho! It seems chess isn't your strong suit either, Captain! I take down the Morganas, I create the combat plans. What is it you do again aside from bark orders?

Fields.MenuText: A rematch! Right now!

Fields.DialogueText: I never agreed to such a thing. Be honest, would you have allowed me such mercy?

Fields.MenuText: It looks like Moses is bad luck after all.

Fields.DialogueText: He kept you alive for far longer than I expected. I'd say that was pretty lucky all things considered.

Fields.MenuText: Next time we play "who has more medals of honor..."

Fields.DialogueText: As long as after that, for the tiebreaker, we play "who can take down the most Morganas in a minute with their bare hands!"
Very well. A deal's a deal. What do you want from me?
*ALARM*
Oh so very many things, Captain. A house by the sea, a car with a driver. Right this instant, I'd like you to join me in taking down these Morganas.
But as for our agreement, I said I would let you know and that is just what I'll do.
I'm shaking already...
Worry not, Captain. I would never allow my beloved to come to any harm. Now, shall we?
Your reassurance has only filled me with more fear...
@BATTLE
Explain to me again what exactly it is you want from me.
It's simple, Captain. All I ask of you is that you sign this piece of paper without reading it.
Uh-huh... May I ask--
No.
I see. Is there any way I can--
None whatsoever.
Hmm... You put me in a real pickle here, Cossack. I pride myself on upholding my word, but I can't in good conscience sign the lives of my crew away by accident.
What kind of monster do you think I am?

Fields.MenuText: Could you give me a hint as to what this contract is about?

Fields.DialogueText: It concerns no one else but you and I, Captain. Hopefully, that will allow you to rest easy.

Fields.MenuText: Will anyone get hurt by my signing of this?

Fields.DialogueText: No, but should you prolong this any further, MY feelings may start to sting.

Fields.MenuText: I'm still not sure...

Fields.DialogueText: I didn't realise I had devoted myself to a promise-breaker. I'll be sure to inform the Navy when I apply for a transfer.
*ALARM*
The Morganas are beating down our door, Captain...
Blast it all! *Scribble scribble* There! Now, if you wouldn't mind...
Lovely! I'm right behind you, Captain!
@BATTLE
Is it time for me to finally learn of my fate?
Very well. Here you are.
What is this?
A vow. With the recent battles we've been through, I've been worrying more and more that your views may change towards me.

Fields.MenuText: Why do you say that?

Fields.DialogueText: My views concerning bad luck have been uprooted. That is something I never thought would happen until the day I die. I can see now that people's minds are more fickle than I thought.
So, this is kind of like... a wedding vow?
Captain, please! This is nothing of the sort! I just want it in writing that you promise to stay by my side from now until eternity.
That's the literal definition of a--
Knowing this, would you like to remove your signature?

Fields.MenuText: They would never!

Fields.DialogueText: You say that, but...

Fields.MenuText: I'll get angry if you speak like that.

Fields.DialogueText: Having doubts is only human, Captain. Or... Belle, in this case.
Knowing what I know, I'd write it a thousand times over.
*ALARM*
Now stop talking nonsense. We have business to attend to.
*Exhale*
Cossack? Everything all right?
Da, Captain. Just... a weight feels like it's been lifted. I'm fine. Shall we?
@BATTLE
We're under siege! Men to your positions!
They're too much for us, Captain! Suggest we tactically retreat and regroup after coming up with a plan!

Fields.MenuText: Dear God... Cossack's been infected by a Morgana virus!
Excellent idea, Cossack! You lot heard the Belle! Move it!

Fields.DialogueText: I'll help out as well!
This is no time for teasing, Captain!

Fields.MenuText: I was planning on blasting through them!

Fields.DialogueText: And get yourself killed?! I don't think so. We're falling back!
*BOOM*
They're not going to let us go quietly into the night, it seems.
I'll lay down suppressing fire! Just get to safety!
Right!
@BATTLE
Keep retreating, Captain! I'll be with you shortly!
@BATTLE
Phew! We made it!
Thanks to your forward thinking, Cossack. Whether it be chess or warfare, you're a tactician through and through.
I never thought of myself as such. I've always prioritized completing my mission as quickly as possible, regardless of the casualties.

Fields.MenuText: You've grown, as have we all. War changes people.

Fields.DialogueText: That it does. Hopefully, any future changes are just as favorable.

Fields.MenuText: Now, if only we could get you to care about the rest of the human race.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, I care, Captain. I would not be fighting the good fight for a cause I didn't believe in. It is for the sake of the human race's future that some may have to be sacrificed.

Fields.MenuText: Do you agree now that retreating should not be seen as cowardice?

Fields.DialogueText: It is still cowardly in my opinion. However, some things are worth losing a little face over.
Cossack, let's adjourn to my quarters. We'll think up a great plan alongside Moses for how to stick it to those Morganas from earlier.
And we'll do it without losing a single soul.
That's my girl.
And I wouldn't have it any other way!
